thread.title: Dolphins' offense stocked with homegrown talent
thread.title_full: Dolphins' offense stocked with homegrown talent

author: Chris Perkins
title: Dolphins' offense stocked with homegrown talent
text:
Dolphins' offense stocked with homegrown talent Dolphins need to utilize running game against Texans 
Chris Perkins and Omar Kelly preview Sunday's Dolphins-Texans game. 
Chris Perkins and Omar Kelly preview Sunday's Dolphins-Texans game. Chris Perkins Contact Reporter Sun Sentinel Nine of 11 starters on Dolphins' offense were drafted by the team 
Nine of the Dolphins' 11 offensive starters are homegrown talents, players drafted and developed by the front office and coaching staff. Only left tackle Branden Albert and tight end Jordan Cameron were selected by another team. 
So when wide receiver Rishard Matthews, a seventh-round pick in 2012, took a huge hit last Sunday against Tennessee and bounced back up it could have been a metaphor for the Dolphins' recent offensive draftees. 
When the Dolphins (2-3) take the field Sunday against Houston (2-4) with their re-energized offense it'll be a direct reflection of years of hard work by the organization. 
With center Mike Pouncey (first round, 2011), left guard Dallas Thomas (third round, 2013), right guard Billy Turner (third round, 2013), right tackle Ja'Wuan James (first round, 2014), tight end Dion Sims (fourth round, 2013), quarterback Ryan Tannehill (first round, 2012), running back Lamar Miller (fourth round, 2012), wide receiver Jarvis Landry (second round, 2014), and Matthews, the Dolphins are putting their "draft and develop" philosophy to work. 
"It makes a difference," Dolphins interim coach Dan Campbell said. "Here's the thing, when you draft your guys then you know you're probably going to keep them around for a while because you've invested money in them." Caption Full Episode: Have Dolphins transformed from finesse to physical team? 
X's and Omar: Sun-Sentinel's Omar Kelly and CBS 12's Matt Lincoln discuss the Dolphins situation as they prepare for the Texans. 
X's and Omar: Sun-Sentinel's Omar Kelly and CBS 12's Matt Lincoln discuss the Dolphins situation as they prepare for the Texans. Caption Full Episode: Have Dolphins transformed from finesse to physical team? 
X's and Omar: Sun-Sentinel's Omar Kelly and CBS 12's Matt Lincoln discuss the Dolphins situation as they prepare for the Texans. 
X's and Omar: Sun-Sentinel's Omar Kelly and CBS 12's Matt Lincoln discuss the Dolphins situation as they prepare for the Texans. Caption Part 1: Can Lamar Miller carry Dolphins? 
X's and Omar: Sun-Sentinel's Omar Kelly and CBS 12's Matt Lincoln discuss whether Lamar Miller can sustain Dolphins' rejuvenated rushing attack. 
X's and Omar: Sun-Sentinel's Omar Kelly and CBS 12's Matt Lincoln discuss whether Lamar Miller can sustain Dolphins' rejuvenated rushing attack. Caption Part 2: Who will stop J.J. Watt? 
X's and Omar: Sun-Sentinel's Omar Kelly and CBS 12's Matt Lincoln brace themselves for the powerhouse that is J.J. Watt. 
X's and Omar: Sun-Sentinel's Omar Kelly and CBS 12's Matt Lincoln brace themselves for the powerhouse that is J.J. Watt. Caption Part 3: Can Campbell's physical Dolphins continue to win? 
X's and Omar: Sun-Sentinel's Omar Kelly and CBS 12's Matt Lincoln talk about the future of Dan Campbell's physical Dolphins team. 
X's and Omar: Sun-Sentinel's Omar Kelly and CBS 12's Matt Lincoln talk about the future of Dan Campbell's physical Dolphins team. Caption Can Dolphins become physical overnight? 
X's and Omar: Sun-Sentinel's Omar Kelly and CBS 12's Matt Lincoln weigh in on the Dolphins attempting to become a more physical team. 
X's and Omar: Sun-Sentinel's Omar Kelly and CBS 12's Matt Lincoln weigh in on the Dolphins attempting to become a more physical team. 
Defensively, the homegrown talent is coming along much more slowly. 
Only four of the 11 starters — defensive end Olivier Vernon (third round, 2012), linebacker Koa Misi (second round, 2010), linebacker Jelani Jenkins (fourth round, 2013) and strong safety Reshad Jones (fifth round, 2010) — were drafted and developed by the Dolphins (defensive end Cameron Wake was signed by the Dolphins after excelling in the Canadian Football League). 
Granted, the Dolphins still have lots of work to do offensively. 
Tannehill, playing behind an offensive line with four of five starters drafted by the Dolphins, has been sacked 12 times, tied for 14th-most in the NFL. Dan Campbell strikes again 
Chris Perkins and Omar Kelly discuss the latest motivational ploy by Dolphins interim coach Dan Campbell as well as Thursday's other practice news. 
Chris Perkins and Omar Kelly discuss the latest motivational ploy by Dolphins interim coach Dan Campbell as well as Thursday's other practice news. See more videos 
The rushing offense is 26th (91.4 yards per game) in the league, the passing offense is 16th (247 yards per game), and the scoring offense is 24th (20.6 points per game). 
Only Pouncey has made a Pro Bowl among Miami's group of drafted offensive starters. But a large number of them are playing key roles. 
And when you throw in tight end Charles Clay (sixth round, 2011), who is now in Buffalo, the Dolphins' recent offensive draft picks earn another measure of respect. 
"I think we're all doing a good job at staying relevant," said Matthews, who leads the Dolphins in receiving yards (363) and touchdowns (three) and is second in receptions (23). 
Not all of the Dolphins recent draft picks on offense have worked out.Players such as running back Daniel Thomas (second round, 2011), tight end Michael Egnew (third round, 2012) and tackle Jonathan Martin (second round, 2012) are no longer with the team. 
But others such as Pouncey, Tannehill, Landry and James started as rookies. 
Miller, Thomas, Turner, Sims and Matthews developed later in their careers. 
While struggling at times, and not being full of star players, this crew has developed enough to form the core of a group that could be together for a while. 
"I think the longer you're together," offensive coordinator Bill Lazor said, "the more chances you have to have success." 
The Dolphins still have other offensive draftees in the wings, most notably wide receiver DeVante Parker, this year's first-round pick. Campbell called Parker a "flash player," meaning he flashes signs of promise. 
"As soon as those flashes start showing up a lot more often," Campbell said, "that's when you feel good about getting him on the field." 
Matthews, by the way, was running a slant pattern when he absorbed that big hit against the Titans. But he got up, and then enthusiastically signaled "first down." 
Just as it happened with the Dolphins' recent offensive draftees, the payoff came after the initial hit. 
"I was able to swag on him after," Matthews said with a smile.
